docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 17 -- It's become some kind of a 16-year-old rite of spring when annually the movers and shakers of Washington's several worlds of society, art, politics and diplomacy gather at the Corcoran Gallery of Art to have a ball.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 17 -- It's become some kind of a 16-year-old rite of spring when annually the movers and shakers of Washington's several worlds of society, art, politics and diplomacy gather at the Corcoran Gallery of Art to have a ball.
docs.abstract: Wilfred, Thomas: Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington, DC, holds annual ball in connection with retrospective of Wilfred's light art; Secs Romney, Richardson and Hodgson, Sens Bayh and Saxbe, other notables from worlds of society, art and politics attend; illus; Museum of Modern Art prints curator D Stein organized show; says Wilfred, who died in '68 at age of 79, is 'father of light art in America'

headline.main: A Ball That Had Something for Everybody From Washington's Different Worlds

byline.original: By ROSEMARY DONIHISpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: QUITO, Ecuador, April 27 -All over South America, nations that for 20 years planned, trained and equipped their armed forces with United States guidance and supplies have been ordering jet interceptors and warships, automatic weapons and tanks from...
docs.lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador, April 27 -All over South America, nations that for 20 years planned, trained and equipped their armed forces with United States guidance and supplies have been ordering jet interceptors and warships, automatic weapons and tanks from Western Europe.
docs.abstract: Latin-Amer nations increasingly turn to W Eur for arms, nullifying effect of US ban on advanced arms sale enacted 6 yrs ago to encourage nations to spend more on econ development and soc reform; trend of expansion and modernization of armed forces results from variety of motivations and pressures, most important of which is natl defense

headline.main: Latin Lands Turning to Europe for Arms; Latin Lands Turning to Europe For Arms U.S. Won't Supply

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Nixon has exercised his option to exceed the ceiling of $75-million a year set by Congress in 1967 on United States arms aid to Latin America exclusive of training. He has also recommended to Congress that the ceiling...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Nixon has exercised his option to exceed the ceiling of $75-million a year set by Congress in 1967 on United States arms aid to Latin America exclusive of training. He has also recommended to Congress that the ceiling next year be raised to $150-million.
docs.abstract: Pres Nixon moves to exceed ceiling on US arms aid to Latin Amer from $75-million to $150-million a yr exclusive of mil training; move is reptdly intended to give US more flexibility in granting Latin-Amer requests for arms aid and to open Latin-Amer markets to US mfrs; decision reptd made in Apr on recommendation of Sec Rogers, citing US security, declining influence in hemisphere attributed to aid cutbacks and other reasons, but action was not reptd to Cong until early May; Repr Fascell questions timing of waiver, hints at attempt to avoid Cong rev; raises other questions on US-Latin Amer ties; details of US contracts for arms sales closely held by Adm officials who insist no approvals have been made but concede waiver reflects mounting pressure for purchases

headline.main: Nixon Moving to Meet Latin Pleas for More Arms Aid

docs.snippet: It is clear that the self-appointed "Turkish People's Liberation Army," which murdered Israel's Consul General in Istanbul, has no support whatever from the Turkish people. And there is no evidence that the "Revolutionary Army of the People," which...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is clear that the self-appointed "Turkish People's Liberation Army," which murdered Israel's Consul General in Istanbul, has no support whatever from the Turkish people. And there is no evidence that the "Revolutionary Army of the People," which abducted Britain's honorary consul in Rosario, gets any backing from the people of Argentina.
docs.abstract: ed says Elrom killing illustrates how difficult it is for any govt to prevent gangsters with no popular support from employing tactic of kidnapping or to cope with it effectively after it has occurred; says Turkish Govt's uncompromising stance was praised when 4 US airmen were released unharmed and unransomed and cannot be criticized now even though it tragically failed to save Elrom

docs.snippet: American workers spend an average of 16 minutes each way going to and from work, and 81 per cent of them do their traveling by automobile, the Gallup Poll asserts.
docs.lead_paragraph: American workers spend an average of 16 minutes each way going to and from work, and 81 per cent of them do their traveling by automobile, the Gallup Poll asserts.
docs.abstract: Gallup Poll survey of US and 7 foreign nations shows percentage of people who go to and from work by autos; W Ger leads with 45%; table

headline.main: Gallup Poll Asserts 81% in U.S. Use Automobiles to Get to Work

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator William Proxmire charged today that the Inter-American Development Bank "spent exorbitant sums" in connection with its last two annual meetings in Uruguay and Peru.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator William Proxmire charged today that the Inter-American Development Bank "spent exorbitant sums" in connection with its last two annual meetings in Uruguay and Peru.
docs.abstract: Sen Proxmire, in criticizing Inter-Amer Development Bank spending in connection with its last 2 annual meetings, heightens growing Cong criticism of internatl lending insts through which Pres Nixon hopes to channel increasing proportion of US foreign aid

headline.main: PROXMIRE SCORES LATIN BANK COST; Points to 'Exorbitant Sums' for Its Annual Meetings PROXMIRE SCORES LATIN BANK COST

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 -Brazil has joined five other South American countries that are apparently frozen into a diplomatic confrontation with the United States over control of coastal waters in general and over fishing rights in particular.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 -Brazil has joined five other South American countries that are apparently frozen into a diplomatic confrontation with the United States over control of coastal waters in general and over fishing rights in particular.
docs.abstract: Brazil joins Ecuador, Argentina, Chile, Peru and Uruguay in claiming control over 200-mile limit of its coast; navy now patrolling coastal waters in search of offenders; Brazilian officials estimate annual catch by foreign boats was worth $20-million in '70; US dispute with S Amer countries over 200-mi limit revd

headline.main: Brazil Stands Firm on 200-Mile Sea Limit and Joins Five Other Latin Nations in Conflict With U.S.
